intro: Silene scabriflora subsp. macrocalycina, commonly known as the roughleaf sandpink, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its upright, branched stems and narrow, linear leaves that are covered in fine, stiff hairs. The flowers are typically pink to red in color, with five petals and prominent stamens, and are arranged in dense clusters at the ends of the stems. This subspecies is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments, often growing in sandy or gravelly soils. Its botanical features make it a distinctive member of the Caryophyllaceae family, with ecological significance in its native range.
